In the contemporary sense, climate change is the most serious environmental threat tofood security in Nigeria as in other parts of the world. facing most Nigerians. The climate change Vulnerability Index 2014 classified Nigeria#s vulnerability as extreme and ranked the country as the fourth (4th) most vulnerable, in the World, to climate change. According to some reports, by 2020, if no mitigation or effective adaptations measures are implemented, between 2% and 11%, the Gross Domestic Product(GDP) of most communities could be lost to any climate change related mishaps (DFID, 2009).In addition, many Nigerians could become food insecure and malnourished. Two factors are the key drivers of climate change in Nigeria, which are gas flaringand depletion of forests. Gas-flaring (Udok and Akpan, 2017) . Gas-flaring is as old as the discovery of crude oil in Nigeria and it remains a global environmental malaise with its attendant environmental consequences. Literature asserts that, Nigeria accounts for an estimatedtwo billion standard cubic feet of gas flared annually, and which amountstoabout 19 percent of gas flared globally. The alarming depletion of tropical forests (Ogbodo et al., 2017) is another key driver of climate change. Consequently, most forest vegetationin Africa is basically declining due to deliberate removal oftreesto pave way for mineral exploitation, urban sprawl, agricultural expansion and infrastructural development. Whereas, promoting good nutrition, health and sustainable food systems in the context of population growth, competing claims (as highlightedabove)for natural resources; and a changing climate are central challenges in ourcontemporary African societies. Thus the combined effect of gas flaring and forest depletion is a negation of the principle of sustainable development, whereby meeting the needsofthe present population are met without compromising the ability of future human generations to meet their own needs as well.
Against this background, the need to influence public policies and private activities becomes paramount, which to a large measure border as much on policies of government to provide infrastructure as also on the activities of private sector in enterprise. In both cases, thelack of transparency and inadequate information flow constitute a major constraint to the attainmentof national food security and right to food in Nigeria.

participating-org.narrative:
Established in 1969, YMCA Mada Hills is an affiliate of the Young men#s Christian Association of Nigeria. The organisation#s mission is to facilitate relevant community based programmes and services that empower young people and the vulnerable on the basis of equality and justice and for self-reliance. YMCA Hills in Lafia is a local partner to Oxfam Novib in project VSLA and Empower @ Scale. oung Men's Christian Association of Nigeria (YMCA) will focus on implementing the project in Nasarawa State. Young Men Christian Association of Nigeria will trained eleven (11) field officers and fifty five(55) village agents in Village Savings and Loans Association (VSLA) methodologies. These trained officers will then facilitate the stepping down of the training for 1500 VSLA members on community-based micro-credit scheme, entrepreneurship and leadership. During the year, the field officers will identify strong 50 women leaders from the savings groups that will be further trained and certified as village agents. The 55 village agents will help spread the formation of new groups quickly to reach the desired number by end of year.
Oxfam will carryout community engagement and relationship building based on gender analysis and power mapping to address the underlying causes to vulnerability. Oxfam will empower the members of the VSLAs to be able to lead in awareness creation on gender related issuesand balance gender roles. On average, each member of a VS<(>&<)>LA will influence 2 external people among which her/hispartner. Father#s groups will be formed to interface with VS<(>&<)>LA and the wider communities on gender relations. Male members of VS<(>&<)>LAs will be represented in father#s groups to bridge the gap between VS<(>&<)>LA and the wider communities. Oxfam staff and trainedfield officers will use the Women#s EconomicLeadership (WEL) and the Women#s Economic Empowerment (WEE) knowledge hub resources to facilitate these discussions and promote regular contact between the VS<(>&<)>LA groups and support services. At the end of theprocess, at least 30 change agents will emerge from VS<(>&<)>LA and father#s groups: 500 strong female leaders and 10 male gender champions/models.
